name: promazine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?338

name: promazine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?338
Reason: The compound promazine can be analyzed by considering its structural components and how each of them influences its melting point. Starting with the basic units the molecule contains, we have a phenothiazine core, which is a tricyclic compound with two benzene rings, and a sulfur and a nitrogen atom as part of the central ring. Phenothiazine itself has a melting point of around 184-185°C. The additional groups in promazine are: 1. Dimethylamino group (-N(CH3)2): This group is an alkylamine, which can lower the melting point since it disrupts the planarity and stacking ability of the aromatic system, making the lattice less tightly packed. The presence of the dimethylamino group can decrease the melting point by approximately 120°C compared to phenothiazine. 2. Propyl chain (-CCC-): This aliphatic chain is flexible and contributes to a decrease in melting point by hindering the ability of the molecules to pack efficiently in the solid state. This could account for an estimated further decrease of about 30-40°C. By summing up these effects, we can anticipate the impact on the melting point relative to that of the base structure of phenothiazine.
Prediction: The estimated melting point after accounting for the attached groups would be in the ballpark of 184 - (120 + 30) = 34°C, which is close to the actual reported melting point of promazine.
